flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
The Problem

We worked with a man who has ALS, a progressive motor neuron disease that has claimed his ability to voluntarily manipulate his body from the neck down. He cannot talk, but can shake his head yes or no, as well as move his eyes and to some extent his mouth. He has no cognitive deficits. He uses a wheelchair, and attached to that chair is a tablet computer. This computer, through the use of software and an attached camera, allows him to communicate with the outside world. He inputs text and uses the mouse via eye gaze, which is effective, but much slower than traditional keyboard/mouse input, and has the computer speak what he wants to say.

This man is very independent and still pursuing a career. Although his home is an augmentative living center, he goes out alone without prior notice, for work reasons or just to visit the nearby park. When he is out, he has no way of communicating with the staff at his living center or emergency services if anything were to happen.

Our client wanted a device to help him communicate with the staff at his living center (send and receive short text-based messages) and to call for medical help quickly when he is outside. His tablet computer does not have any Internet connectivity and he owns no cell phone. The computer does have USB ports that offer power, two large speakers, and the eye camera previously mentioned. Our client’s wheelchair runs off of a 220V battery.
